Calculus Ashan J 2025-07-18 Chapter 1 Introduction Calculus, often regarded as one of the pillars of mathematics, serves as the bridge between theoretical concepts and their practical applications. It is the language that allows us to quantify change, understand behavior, and make predictions in diverse fields ranging from physics and engineering to economics and biology. This book is designed to guide you through the foundational principles of calculus, building an intuitive understanding while fostering a rigorous approach to problem-solving. Starting with the concept of functions, you will explore their properties, transformations, and inverse relationships. From there, we delve into the profound concepts of limits and continuity, the cornerstone of calculus that enables us to make sense of infinitesimal changes and instantaneous rates. Differentiation will provide the tools to understand the slope of curves, optimize functions, and reveal the geometry of graphs. The exploration of sequences and series will demonstrate how seemingly infinite processes can be summed and analyzed with precision. Ultimately, the study of infinite series will unveil the power of calculus in capturing the essence of infinite behavior within finite bounds. Through a combination of intuitive explanations, precise mathematical definitions, and illustrative examples, this book aims to not only teach calculus but to spark an appreciation for its elegance and utility. Whether you are embarking on a journey of discovery or honing your mathematical expertise, the concepts presented within these pages are bound to enrich your perspective of the world around you. Let us begin this exciting journey into the infinite possibilities of calculus.

Chapter 4 Differentiation 4.1 Introduction Having established both conceptual understanding and computational techniques for limits, we now possess the fundamental tools necessary for studying calculus. Calculus encompasses the mathematical discipline concerned with derivatives and integrals. Historical consensus attributes the independent development of calculus to Isaac Newton of England and Gottfried Leibniz of Germany. Their crucial contribution was recognizing the fundamental relationship connecting derivatives and integrals. The derivative generalizes the notion of slope from straight lines to arbitrary functions. We begin by examining the familiar concept of slope. 4.1.1 Linear Functions and Slope A straight line represents a one-dimensional geometric object of zero width, conceptualized as an infinite collection of connected points without curvature. Definition 4.1 (Slope) The slope (also called gradient, incline, or pitch) quantifies the steepness of a straight line. Key properties include: The slope remains constant throughout the entire line Greater slope values correspond to steeper lines Slope indicates the line’s directional behavior (increasing or decreasing) Slope represents the rate of change Theorem 4.1 (Slope Formula) For a straight line passing through points \(P(x_1, y_1)\) and \(Q(x_2, y_2)\), the slope is: \[m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}\] Remark (Linear Equations). Straight lines can be expressed in various forms: Slope-intercept form: \(y = mx + c\) (where \(m\) is slope and \(c\) is y-intercept) Point-slope form: \(y = m(x - x_1) + y_1\) (passing through point \((x_1, y_1)\)) 4.1.2 Applications of Slope Slope provides valuable information across numerous contexts. For instance, a mountain’s slope indicates its steepness, while in physics, slope might represent velocity, acceleration, or other rates of change. Video Consider an object travelling 20 meters in 5 seconds. The slope calculation yields: \[\text{Speed} = \frac{\text{change in }y}{\text{change in }x}=\frac{\text{change in distance}}{\text{change in time}}=\frac{20 \text{ meters}}{5 \text{ seconds}} = 4 \text{ meters per second}\] 4.1.3 The Challenge of Curved Functions Most real-world applications involve curved rather than linear graphs. Unfortunately, curved functions present a fundamental challenge: their rate of change varies continuously from point to point, making the standard slope formula inapplicable. Example 4.1 (Position Function) Consider a car whose position follows \(f(t) = t^2\). To find the speed at \(t = 1\) second, we might attempt using the slope formula with different point pairs: Points \((1,1)\) and \((2,4)\): \[m = \frac{4-1}{2-1} = 3\] Points \((1,1)\) and \((3,9)\): \[m = \frac{9-1}{3-1} = 4\] This yields two different “slopes” at \(t = 1\), but the car should have exactly one speed at that instant. 4.1.4 Secant and Tangent Lines To resolve this dilemma, we introduce two fundamental concepts: Definition 4.2 (Secant Line) A secant line is a straight line connecting two distinct points on a function’s graph. Definition 4.3 (Tangent Line) A tangent line is a straight line that “just touches” a curve at exactly one point, representing the instantaneous direction of the curve at that point. 4.1.5 From Average to Instantaneous Rates In our car example, the value 3 represents the slope of the secant line through \((1,1)\) and \((2,4)\), giving the average speed between \(t = 1\) and \(t = 2\). Similarly, 4 represents the average speed between \(t = 1\) and \(t = 3\). However, we seek the instantaneous speed at \(t = 1\) - the speedometer reading at that precise moment. This corresponds to the slope of the tangent line at that point. The challenge lies in computing the tangent line’s slope using the two-point slope formula when we know only one point on the tangent line. The derivative resolves this by expressing the tangent line’s slope as the limit of secant line slopes as the second point approaches the first. 4.2 Definition of the Derivative Definition 4.4 (Derivative) Let \(f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\). At a point \((x_0, f(x_0))\), if the limit \[ \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)}{h} \] exists, then this limit represents the slope of the tangent line to the curve at \((x_0, f(x_0))\). When this limit exists, we say that \(f\) is differentiable at \(x_0\). Video Important Notes: This is a two-sided limit, meaning \(h\) approaches zero from both positive and negative directions. The slope of the tangent line to \(f(x)\) at \(x_0\) is called the derivative of \(f\) at \(x = x_0\). Example 4.2 (Derivative of $f(x) = x^2$) Let \(f(x) = x^2\). We want to find the derivative of $f Video To find the slope of the tangent line to \(f(x) = x^2\) at \(x = x_0\): \[\begin{align} m_{x_0} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(x_0 + h)^2 - x_0^2}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{x_0^2 + 2x_0h + h^2 - x_0^2}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{2x_0h + h^2}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} (2x_0 + h) \\ &= 2x_0 \end{align}\] Notice that the derivative of \(f(x) = x^2\) depends on \(x\). In general, the derivative of a function is itself a function. 4.3 Derivative Notation 4.3.1 Lagrange’s Notation The derivative of \(f(x)\) is denoted as \(f'(x)\). Example 4.3 If \(f(x) = x^2\), then \(f'(x) = 2x\). 4.3.2 Leibniz Notation The derivative of \(f(x)\) is denoted as \(\frac{df}{dx}\) or \(\frac{d}{dx}f(x)\). Example 4.4 If \(f(x) = x^2\), then \(\frac{d}{dx}f(x) = 2x\) If \(y = t^2\), then \(\frac{dy}{dt} = 2t\) The variable in the denominator (e.g., \(x\) in \(\frac{d}{dx}\)) indicates the variable of differentiation. 4.4 Derivatives of Standard Functions 4.4.0.1 Constant Function Function \(f(x) = k\) where \(k\) is a constant. Derivative \(f'(x) = 0\) Proof. \[\begin{align} f'(x) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{k - k}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{0}{h} = 0 \end{align}\] 4.4.0.2 Power Rule Function \(f(x) = x^n\) where \(n\) is a positive integer. Derivative \(f'(x) = nx^{n-1}\) Proof. for \(f(x) = x^3\) \[\begin{align} \frac{df}{dx} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(x + h)^3 - x^3}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{x^3 + 3x^2h + 3xh^2 + h^3 - x^3}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{3x^2h + 3xh^2 + h^3}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} (3x^2 + 3xh + h^2) \\ &= 3x^2 \end{align}\] Proof. **General proof for \(f(x) = x^n\) Using the binomial theorem: \[\begin{align} (x + h)^n &= \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^{n-k} h^k \\ &= x^n + nx^{n-1}h + \frac{n(n-1)}{2}x^{n-2}h^2 + \ldots + h^n \end{align}\] Therefore: \[\begin{align} \frac{df}{dx} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(x + h)^n - x^n}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{nx^{n-1}h + \frac{n(n-1)}{2}x^{n-2}h^2 + \ldots + h^n}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \left(nx^{n-1} + \frac{n(n-1)}{2}x^{n-2}h + \ldots + h^{n-1}\right) \\ &= nx^{n-1} \end{align}\] 4.4.0.3 Linear Function Function\(f(x) = mx + c\) where \(m, c \in \mathbb{R}\) are constants. Derivative \(f'(x) = m\) Proof. \[\begin{align} f'(x) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{m(x + h) + c - (mx + c)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{mh}{h} \\ &= m \end{align}\] This confirms that the derivative of a linear function equals its slope. 4.4.0.4 Trigonometric Functions Function\(f(x) = \sin(x)\) Derivative \(f'(x) = \cos(x)\) Proof. \[\begin{align} \frac{df}{dx} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(x + h) - \sin(x)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{2\cos\left(\frac{2x + h}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{h}{2}\right)}{h} \\ &= \cos(x) \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin\left(\frac{h}{2}\right)}{\frac{h}{2}} \\ &= \cos(x) \cdot 1 = \cos(x) \end{align}\] Similarly \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\) Exercise 4.1 Proove that \(\frac{d}{dx}[\cos(x)] = -\sin(x)\) 4.4.0.5 Square Root Function Function\(f(x) = \sqrt{x}\) Derivative \(f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\) 4.4.1 Summary Table Function Type Function Derivative Notes Constant \(f(x) = k\) \(f'(x) = 0\) Where \(k\) is any constant Power Rule \(f(x) = x^n\) \(f'(x) = nx^{n-1}\) Where \(n\) is a positive integer Linear \(f(x) = mx + c\) \(f'(x) = m\) Where \(m, c \in \mathbb{R}\) are constants Sine \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) \(f'(x) = \cos(x)\) Cosine \(f(x) = \cos(x)\) \(f'(x) = -\sin(x)\) Square Root \(f(x) = \sqrt{x}\) \(f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\) 4.5 Existence of Derivative We have introduced the definition of derivatives and observed the use of the definition to compute derivatives. All the examples up now involved differentiable functions; in this section, we see examples of functions and points where the function is not differentiable. Example 4.5 Let \(f(x) = |x|\). Chapter 5 Sequence 5.1 The \(\epsilon- N\) Definition of a Limit of Sequence Definition 5.1 (The epsilon− N Definition of a Limit of Sequence) The number \(L\) is the limit of the sequence \(\{a_n\}\). If for each \(\epsilon> 0 , \exists N \in \mathbb{R}\),such that \[n > N \implies |a_n − L| < \epsilon.\] Now let us look at examples demonstrating the use of the \(\epsilon - N\) definition in proofs. Note that the definition provides no help in postulating the value of the limit. It is only applicable when proving that the postulated value is correct. As we are concentrating on the proofs, in the upcoming examples, we will provide the value of the limits. Before that, let us concentrate on some technical aspects of the definition. To establish the \(\epsilon - N\) definition in a proof: For each \(\epsilon > 0\), you must guarantee the existence of an \(N\) such that the condition \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\) is satisfied for all \(n > N\). It is required to develop an argument that will work for any given \(\epsilon\). To achieve this, adhere to the following principles: Start the proof by saying, “Let \(\epsilon > 0\).” Throughout the proof, do not make any “special” assumptions1. You cannot choose the \(\epsilon\) value (you can only assume that \(\epsilon > 0\)). The phrase “there exists” in a mathematical statement is always a signal for a scavenger hunt. In this case: First, somehow find a starting \(N\) value. Show that for any \(n > N\), the condition \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\) is satisfied. The epsilon definition does not provide a method to find the starting \(N\) value. In proofs, it is not required to describe how you found the starting \(N\) value. As long as there are correct arguments to establish that “all \(a_n\) afterwards \(N\) satisfy the necessary condition,” the proof is valid. Even though it is not required to explain how you found it, you still need an \(N\). The following technique can help get the wheels in motion. You are expected to show that \(a_n\) values after \(N\) satisfy the inequality \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\). Therefore, start with the inequality \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\) and think backward to figure out a possible starting \(N\). Once you determine \(N\), you can construct the formal proof to establish that the \(a_n\) values after \(N\) satisfy the necessary condition. Example 5.1 Prove that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0. \] We have to prove that \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0\). There are two aspects associated with this statement: the intuitive meaning and the proper mathematical semantics. Since we are writing a proof, let us focus on the mathematical semantics. According to the definition, to prove this, we have to establish that: For each \(\epsilon > 0\), \(\exists N \in \mathbb{R}\), such that \(n > N \implies \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon\). Now let us start the hunt for \(N\). The steps below describe the backward thinking process. These are just scratch work and do not need to follow rigorous rules. We are looking for \(N\) such that \(n > N \implies \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon\). Let us start with the inequality: \[ \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon \] and try to isolate \(n\). \[ \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon \tag{3.1} \] \[ \left| \frac{1}{n} \right| < \epsilon \tag{3.2} \] \[ \frac{1}{n} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } \frac{1}{n} > 0, \text{ we can drop the absolute value}) \tag{3.3} \] \[ \frac{1}{\epsilon} < n \quad (\text{since } n > 0, \epsilon > 0) \tag{3.4} \] Now that we know the starting \(N\) value, we can present the formal proof. Proof. Let \(\epsilon > 0\). Choose \(N = \frac{1}{\epsilon}\). Then for \(n > N\), we have: \[ n > \frac{1}{\epsilon} \tag{3.5} \] \[ \implies \frac{1}{n} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } n > 0, \epsilon > 0) \tag{3.6} \] \[ \implies \left| \frac{1}{n} \right| < \epsilon \tag{3.7} \] \[ \implies \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon. \tag{3.8} \] Thus, for each \(\epsilon > 0\), \(\exists N = \frac{1}{\epsilon} \in \mathbb{R}\), such that \(n > N \implies \left| \frac{1}{n} - 0 \right| < \epsilon\). Observe that: Remark. We construct the proof by reversing steps (3.1) to (3.4). So, when you originally simplify, ensure that you are backtracking the steps. We did not enforce additional restrictions on \(\epsilon\). It is not required to choose an integer as the starting \(N\) value. For example, the \(N\) value for \(\epsilon = 0.3\) is \(N = \frac{1}{0.3} = 3.33\). In this case, \(n > N\) refers to the terms \(a_4, a_5, a_6, \dots\). Remark. This proof can be used as a blueprint: Start the hunt for \(N\) by setting \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\) as in step (3.1). Get an upper estimate for \(|a_n - L| < \epsilon\). In most cases, you can simplify this to \(\frac{k}{n} < \epsilon\). If possible, drop the absolute value. Remember that you are working in reverse; therefore, you can replace the lesser side of the inequality with an upper bound at any step. Choose an upper bound that will help simplify the process of isolating \(n\). Example 5.2 Prove that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n - 200}{n^2} = 0. \] According to the definition, to prove this, we have to establish that: For each \(\epsilon > 0\), \(\exists N \in \mathbb{R}\), such that \(n > N \implies \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} - 0 \right| < \epsilon\). Now let us start the hunt for \(N\): \[ \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} - 0 \right| < \epsilon \tag{3.10} \] \[ \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} \right| < \epsilon \tag{3.11} \] If we can drop the absolute value, we can start isolating \(n\). Notice that if \(n < 200\), the term inside the absolute value is negative. Since we have not yet chosen a starting \(N\) value, we can impose restrictions on \(n\). To keep things positive, we add the condition \(n > 200\). Under this restriction, the term inside the absolute value is always positive. From this point onward, we consider only \(n > 200\). \[ \frac{n - 200}{n^2} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } n > 200) \tag{3.12} \] To simplify this inequality and isolate \(n\), we replace \(\frac{n - 200}{n^2}\) with an upper bound. Let us choose an upper bound that will assist in isolating \(n\): \[ \frac{n}{n^2} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since we are working backward}) \tag{3.13} \] Note that \(\frac{n}{n^2} > \frac{n - 200}{n^2}\). While moving forward in the actual proof, we go from (3.13) to (3.12). \[ \frac{1}{n} < \epsilon \quad (\text{by canceling } n) \tag{3.14} \] \[ \frac{1}{\epsilon} < n \quad (\text{since } n > 0, \epsilon > 0) \tag{3.15} \] Now that we know the starting \(N\) value, we can present the formal proof. Proof. Let \(\epsilon > 0\). From (3.15), take \(N = \frac{1}{\epsilon}\) as our starting point. The assumption in step (3.12) forces us to only consider \(n > 200\). Choosing \(N = \max\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}, 200\right)\) satisfies both conditions. \[ n > N \implies n > \frac{1}{\epsilon} \tag{3.16} \] \[ \implies \frac{1}{n} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } n > 0, \epsilon > 0) \tag{3.17} \] \[ \implies \frac{n}{n^2} < \epsilon \tag{3.18} \] \[ \implies \frac{n - 200}{n^2} < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } \frac{n - 200}{n^2} < \frac{n}{n^2}) \tag{3.19} \] \[ \implies \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} \right| < \epsilon \quad (\text{since } n > 200) \tag{3.20} \] \[ \implies \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} - 0 \right| < \epsilon. \tag{3.21} \] Thus, we have proved that for each \(\epsilon > 0\), \(\exists N = \max\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}, 200\right) \in \mathbb{R}\), such that \(n > N \implies \left| \frac{n - 200}{n^2} - 0 \right| < \epsilon\). Therefore, \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n - 200}{n^2} = 0. \] Example 5.3 Prove that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n}{n^2 + 2} = 0. \] We constructed the \(\epsilon - N\) Definition of a Limit of a Sequence from its intuitive notion. Additionally, we expected you to develop the skills to identify and write correct proofs. The ability to read and write grammatically correct proofs is essential. In most cases, this is a skill you must build with experience. There is no universal algorithm that will always work; you have to figure things out on a case-by-case basis. Sometimes, your proofs may be based on intuitive observations. Theorem 5.1 (Uniqueness Theorem for Limits) A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) has at most one limit. Usually, a uniqueness theorem is proved by either direct proof or by contradiction. First, let’s look at the proof by contradiction. Now, let’s move on to the direct proof. We begin the direct proof by stating that there are two limits, \(L_1\) and \(L_2\), but we do not assume that \(L_1 \neq L_2\). The goal is to prove that \(L_1 = L_2\). Since \(L_1\) is a limit, we can make the terms of the sequence arbitrarily close to \(L_1\) by choosing a sufficiently large \(n\). Similarly, since \(L_2\) is a limit, we can make the terms arbitrarily close to \(L_2\) by choosing a sufficiently large \(n\). As the tail of the sequence gets closer and closer to both \(L_1\) and \(L_2\), they must get closer to each other. This observation can be used to prove that \(L_1 = L_2\). Typically, the triangle inequality is used to establish this type of argument in a formal proof. Proof. Let \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L_1\) and \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L_2\). For any given \(\epsilon > 0\), since \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L_1\), there exists \(N_1 \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[ n > N_1 \implies |a_n - L_1| < \frac{\epsilon}{2}. \tag{3.22} \] Similarly, since \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L_2\), there exists \(N_2 \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[ n > N_2 \implies |a_n - L_2| < \frac{\epsilon}{2}. \tag{3.23} \] Let \(N = \max\{N_1, N_2\}\). Now we will use a common trick. For any \(m > N\), \[ |L_1 - L_2| = |L_1 - a_m + a_m - L_2| \tag{3.24} \] \[ \leq |L_1 - a_m| + |a_m - L_2| \quad (\text{by the triangle inequality}) \tag{3.25} \] \[ \leq |a_m - L_1| + |a_m - L_2| \quad (\text{since from (3.22) and (3.23), we have}) \tag{3.26} \] \[ < \frac{\epsilon}{2} + \frac{\epsilon}{2} = \epsilon. \tag{3.27} \] Thus, for each \(\epsilon > 0\), \(|L_1 - L_2| < \epsilon\), and therefore, \(L_1 = L_2\). Proof. Let \(\{a_n\}\) be a convergent sequence, i.e., there exists \(a \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = a. \] Let \(\epsilon = 1\), then there exists \(N \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[ n > N \implies |a_n - a| < 1. \] Thus, \[ -1 < a_n - a < 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad a - 1 < a_n < a + 1. \tag{3.28} \] Now, let \[ L = \min\{a - 1, a_1, a_2, \dots, a_{N+1}\} \quad \text{and} \quad U = \max\{a + 1, a_1, a_2, \dots, a_{N+1}\}. \] Then, \[ L \leq a_n \leq U \quad \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{N}. \] Thus, the sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is bounded. 5.2 Divergent Sequences Definition 5.3 (Divergent Sequences) If a sequence \(\{a_n\}\) does not converge, then it diverges. Divergence can occur in three forms: The sequence \(\{a_n\}\) diverges to \(+\infty\)} (denoted by \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = \infty\)). This means that for every \(M > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{R}\) such that for all \[n > N \implies a_n > M.\] The sequence \(\{a_n\}\) diverges to \(-\infty\)} (denoted by \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = -\infty\)). This means that for every \(M < 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{R}\) such that for all \[n > N \implies a_n < M.\] Otherwise, the sequence \(\{a_n\}\) does not have a limit. As in Definition 3.2.1, the first two cases of Definition 3.3.1 do not provide a method to find the \(N\) value. In proofs, it is not required to describe how you found the \(N\) value. As long as there are correct arguments to establish “terms after \(N\) satisfy the necessary condition,” the proof is valid. Even though it is not required to explain how you found it, you need an \(N\). In most cases, to find the \(N\), start by assuming the necessary condition is satisfied and trace back to figure out a possible \(N\). In doing so, at any step, in the case of positive infinity, you can replace the greater side of the inequality with a lower bound, and in the case of negative infinity, you can replace the lower side of the inequality with an upper bound. Also, as before, it is worth mentioning that it is not required to find the smallest possible \(N\). It is enough that terms after it satisfy the necessary condition; the behaviour of terms before it is irrelevant. Once you figure out the \(N\), you can construct the formal proof establishing that the \(a_n\)’s after \(N\) satisfy the necessary condition. If \(r < 0\), then \(\{r^n\}\) converges or diverges by oscillation. \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{\ln n}{n^p} = 0 \text{ for each } p > 0 \] \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^p}{e^n} = 0 \text{ for each } p \in \mathbb{R} \] \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n^{1/n}} = 1 \] \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{a^{1/n}} = 1 \text{ for each } a > 0 \] \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \left(1 + \frac{x}{n}\right)^n = e^x \text{ for each } x \in \mathbb{R} \] \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{a^n}{n!} = 0 \text{ for each } a \in \mathbb{R} \] 5.5 Exercise Prove the following using the definition of sequence convergence: \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n+1}{n^2+1} = 0\) \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2 - 1}{n^3 + 1} = 0\) \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{\cos n a}{n} = 0\) \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n+1}{\sqrt{n}} = 1\) Let \(a_n = \frac{2n - 2}{\sqrt{5n+1}}\). Chapter 6 Series 6.1 Introduction Let the sequence \(\{S_n\}\) be defined as follows: \[ S_1 = 1 \] \[ S_2 = 1 + 2 = 3 \] \[ S_3 = 1 + 2 + 3 = 6 \] \[ S_4 = 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 = 10 \] By observing \(\{S_n\}\), we conclude that the series \(1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + \dots\) diverges. To determine the behavior of \(1 + 2 + 3 + \dots\), we need to compute \(\lim_{n \to \infty} S_n\). An infinite series, informally speaking, is the sum of the terms of an infinite sequence. It can be expressed in the form: \[ a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + \dots = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i \] The \(n\)th partial sum of the series is: \[ S_n = a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + \dots + a_n = \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i \] The series is said to converge to the sum \(S\) if the sequence of partial sums \(\{S_n\}\) converges to \(S\). In this case, we write: \[ \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = S \] If the sequence does not converge, the series \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i\) diverges and does not have a sum. 6.2 Sequence of Partial Sums Geometric Series A geometric sequence is one where each term is obtained by multiplying the previous term by a fixed ratio \(r\). For example: \(2, 6, 18, 54, \dots\) has a common ratio of \(r = 3\). \(10, 5, 2.5, 1.25, \dots\) has a common ratio of \(r = \frac{1}{2}\). A geometric series has the form: \[ a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + \dots = \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} ar^i \] Theorem 6.1 (The Convergence and Divergence of a Geometric Series) Consider the geometric series: \[ a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + \dots + ar^{n-1} + \dots \] The sequence of partial sums is given by: \[ S_n = \frac{a(1 - r^n)}{1 - r}, \quad \text{when } |r| < 1. \] If \(|r| < 1\), the infinite series converges: \[ \sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i = \frac{a}{1 - r}. \] If \(|r| \geq 1\), the series \(\sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i\) diverges. Proof. \[\begin{eqnarray} S_n &=& a + ar + ar^2 + \dots + ar^{n-1}\\ rS_n &=& ar + ar^2 + \dots + ar^n \\ S_n - rS_n &=& a - ar^n\\ S_n(1 - r) &=& a(1 - r^n)\\ S_n &=& \frac{a(1 - r^n)}{1 - r} \end{eqnarray}\] Taking the limit as \(n \to \infty\): \[\begin{eqnarray} \sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i &=& \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n\\ &=& \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{a(1 - r^n)}{1 - r}\\ &=& \frac{a(1 - \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n)}{1 - r} \\ \end{eqnarray}\] When \(|r| < 1\), \(\lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = 0\), so: \[ \sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i = \frac{a}{1 - r}. \] When \(|r| \geq 1\), the series \(\sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i\) diverges. Example 6.1 Find the Sum of the Following Infinite Series} If it is divergent, write “Diverges.” \(1000, 500, 250, \dots\) This is a geometric series with a common ratio \(r = \frac{1}{2} < 1\), hence: \[ \sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{1000}{1 - \frac{1}{2}} = 2000 \] \(0.1, 0.2, 0.4, \dots\) This is a geometric series with a common ratio \(r = 2\), hence it diverges. \(1, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{4}, \dots\) This is a geometric series with a common ratio \(r = \frac{1}{2} < 1\), hence: \[ \sum_{i=1}^\infty a_i = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{2}} = 2 \] Example 6.2 Consider the Following Series \[ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{3^n} \] Find the values of \(x\) for which the series converges. First, observe that: \[ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{3^n} = \frac{x}{3} + \frac{x^2}{3^2} + \frac{x^3}{3^3} + \dots \] This is a geometric series with a common ratio \(r = \frac{x}{3}\). The series will converge when: \[ \left|\frac{x}{3}\right| < 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad -3 < x < 3 \] Find the sum of the series for those values of \(x\). Write the formula in terms of \(x\). When \(|r| < 1\), the sum of the geometric series is given by: \[\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_i = \frac{a}{1-r}\] Here: \[\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{3^n} = \frac{\frac{x}{3}}{1 - \frac{x}{3}} = \frac{x}{3 - x}\] Remark. The function: \[ f(x) = \frac{x}{3 - x} \] can be expressed as the limit of polynomial functions inside the interval \(-3 < x < 3\): \[ f(x) = \frac{x}{3 - x} = \lim_{k \to \infty} \sum_{n=1}^k \frac{x^n}{3^n}. \] Sometimes, properties of the terms of the sequence will be passed to the limit. Instead of studying the limiting function, we can study the behavior of simpler polynomial functions to understand the limiting function. Example 6.3 Write \(1.\overline{405}\) as a rational number \(\frac{p}{q}\). (The bar over the 405 indicates that this block of digits is to be repeated: \(1.40\overline{5} = 1.405405405\ldots\)) This can be expressed as: \[\begin{align} 1.40\overline{5} &= 1 + \frac{405}{10^3} + \frac{405}{10^6} + \frac{405}{10^9} + \cdots \\ &= 1 + \frac{405}{10^3}\left(1 + \frac{1}{10^3} + \frac{1}{10^6} + \cdots\right) \end{align}\] The series \(\frac{405}{10^3} + \frac{405}{10^6} + \frac{405}{10^9} + \cdots\) is a geometric series with \(a = 1\) and \(r = \frac{1}{10^3}\). \[\begin{align} 1 + \frac{1}{10^3} + \frac{1}{10^6} + \cdots &= \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{1000}} = \frac{1}{\frac{999}{1000}} = \frac{1000}{999} \end{align}\] Therefore: \[\begin{align} 1.\overline{405} &= 1 + \frac{405}{10^3} \cdot \frac{1000}{999} \\ &= 1 + \frac{405}{999} \\ &= \frac{1404}{999} \end{align}\] 6.2.1 Telescoping Series Definition 6.1 A telescoping series is a series whose general term \(t_n\) can be written as \(t_n = a_n - a_{n+1}\), i.e., the difference of two consecutive terms of a sequence. The partial sums of a telescoping series consist of only two terms of \(\{a_n\}\) after cancellation. Example 6.4 Show that the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(k+1)(k+2)}\) converges and find its sum. Let \(a_k = \frac{1}{(k+1)(k+2)}\). Using partial fraction decomposition: \[a_k = \frac{1}{k+1} - \frac{1}{k+2}\] We can use this to get a formula for the \(n\)th partial sum \(S_n\): \[\begin{align} a_1 &= \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{3} \\ a_2 &= \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{4} \\ \vdots &\quad\vdots \quad \vdots \quad \vdots\\ a_{n-1} &= \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1} \\ a_n &= \frac{1}{n+1} - \frac{1}{n+2} \end{align}\] Therefore: \(S_n = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{n+2}\) \[\begin{align} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(k+1)(k+2)} &= \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \left(\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{n+2}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \end{align}\] The series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(k+1)(k+2)}\) converges to \(\frac{1}{2}\). Remark. 6.3 Series Convergence Tests Theorem 6.2 (Divergence Test) If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n\) is not zero, or does not exist, then the series \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i\) diverges. Remark. The divergence test can only tell us that \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i\) diverges if \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \neq 0\). If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0\), the test is inconclusive and cannot be used to show the convergence of a series. For example: \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n^2} = 0\) and series \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2}\) converges \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0\) but series \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n}\) diverges. Example 6.5 Show that the series \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \frac{2n+1}{3n}\) diverges. Let \(a_n = \frac{2n+1}{3n}\). Then: \[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n+1}{3n} = \frac{2}{3}\] Since \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \neq 0\), the divergence test tells us that the series diverges. Remark. Suppose \(\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} a_i\) is a series of non-negative numbers. Then the sequence \(\{S_n\}\) of partial sums is an increasing sequence. From the Bounded Monotonic Sequence Theorem, the sequence of partial sums converges or diverges to \(\infty\), and so does the series. Definition 6.2 (P-Series) A series of the form \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p}\) is called a p-series. Theorem 6.3 (P-Series Test) \[\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p} = \begin{cases} \text{converges} & \text{if } p > 1 \\ \text{diverges} & \text{if } p \leq 1 \end{cases}\] Example 6.6 Test each of the following series for convergence. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}\) \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{k}}\) Solution: \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}} = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^{1/2}}\) Since \(p = \frac{1}{2} < 1\), \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}\) is divergent. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{k}} = 2\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^{3/2}}\) Since \(p = \frac{3}{2} > 1\), \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{k}}\) is convergent. Theorem 6.4 (Direct Comparison Test) Suppose \(0 \leq a_k \leq b_k\) for all \(k\) (\(b_k\) dominates \(a_k\)). If \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) converges, then \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) also converges. If \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) diverges, then \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) also diverges. The above results are also true if the inequalities (dominance) hold for all \(k \geq N\) for some fixed \(N\). Example 6.7 Test the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k + 1}\) for convergence. Observe that \(0 \leq \frac{1}{2^k + 1} \leq \frac{1}{2^k}\) for all \(k\). \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k} = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{8} + \cdots\) is a geometric series with \(r = \frac{1}{2}\), hence \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k}\) converges. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k + 1}\) converges from the direct comparison test. Remark. Given series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) is a series of non-negative numbers. If the given series has the general appearance as another convergent series and if you can show that each term of the given series is smaller than the corresponding term of the convergent series, you can use the direct comparison test to conclude that the given series is convergent. If the given series has the general appearance as another divergent series and if you can show that each term of the given series is larger than the corresponding term of the divergent series, you can use the direct comparison test to conclude that the given series is divergent. When \(a_n\) is defined as a fraction: If you replace the numerator of \(a_n\) by a larger term, then the resulting fraction is larger than \(a_n\). If you replace the numerator of \(a_n\) by a smaller term, then the resulting fraction is smaller than \(a_n\). If you replace the denominator of \(a_n\) by a larger term, then the resulting fraction is smaller than \(a_n\). If you replace the denominator of \(a_n\) by a smaller term, then the resulting fraction is larger than \(a_n\). Example 6.8 Test the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{k+1}{k^2-1}\) for convergence. \(\frac{k+1}{k^2-1} \geq \frac{k}{k^2-1} \geq \frac{k}{k^2} = \frac{1}{k}\) for all \(k\). So \(0 \leq \frac{1}{k} \leq \frac{k+1}{k^2-1}\) for all \(k\). The harmonic series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k}\) diverges. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{k+1}{k^2-1}\) diverges from the direct comparison test. Example 6.9 Test the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{k+8}{k^3+k+8}\) for convergence. Observe that \(\frac{k+8}{k^3+k+8} \leq \frac{k+8}{k^3} \leq \frac{k+k}{k^3} \leq \frac{2k}{k^3} = \frac{2}{k^2}\) for all \(k > 8\). So \(0 \leq \frac{k+8}{k^3+k+8} \leq \frac{2}{k^2}\) for all \(k > 8\). The series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2}{k^2}\) converges from the p-series test. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{k+8}{k^3+k+8}\) converges from the direct comparison test. Remark. We would expect \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k - 5}\) to converge because it is so much like the convergent geometric series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k}\). But \(0 \leq \frac{1}{2^k} \leq \frac{1}{2^k - 5}\). The direct comparison test cannot be used in this situation. We often use the limit comparison test in these situations. Theorem 6.5 (Limit Comparison Test) Suppose \(a_k > 0\) and \(b_k > 0\) for all sufficiently large \(k\) and that \[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} = L\] where \(L\) is finite and positive \((0 < L < \infty)\). Then \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) and \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) either both converge or both diverge. Remark. You are asked to test the convergence of \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\). Find a series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) whose convergent properties are known and whose general term \(b_k\) is essentially the same as \(a_k\). Verify that \(\lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k}\) exists and is positive. Determine whether \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) converges or diverges. Then the limit comparison test tells us that \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) does the same. Example 6.10 Test the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k - 5}\) for convergence. Let \(a_k = \frac{1}{2^k - 5}\) and \(b_k = \frac{1}{2^k}\). \(a_k > 0\) and \(b_k > 0\) for all \(k > 2\). \[\begin{align} \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{2^k - 5}}{\frac{1}{2^k}} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{2^k}{2^k - 5} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{1}{1 - \frac{5}{2^k}} \\ &= 1 \end{align}\] \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k}\) is a geometric series with \(r = \frac{1}{2}\), hence converges. \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^k - 5}\) converges from the limit comparison test. Example 6.11 Test the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k} - 5}\) for convergence. Let \(a_k = \frac{1}{\sqrt{k} - 5}\) and find a series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) whose convergent properties are known and whose general term \(b_k\) is essentially the same as \(a_k\). Since \(\sqrt{k}\) dominates the constant 5, for large \(k\) the series should behave as \(b_k = \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}\). Verify that \(\lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k}\) exists and is positive: \[\begin{align} \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{\sqrt{k} - 5}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\sqrt{k}}{\sqrt{k} - 5} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{1}{1 - \frac{5}{\sqrt{k}}} \\ &= 1 \end{align}\] \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}\) diverges (p-series test). \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k} - 5}\) diverges from the limit comparison test. Example 6.12 Determine whether \(\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{3n + 3}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4}\) converges or diverges. Let \(a_n = \frac{3n + 3}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4}\) and find a series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) whose convergent properties are known and whose general term \(b_n\) is essentially the same as \(a_n\). Fractions involving only polynomials or polynomials under radicals will behave in the same way as the largest power of \(n\) will behave in the limit. So, the terms in this series should behave as: \[b_n = \frac{3n}{8n^5} = \frac{3}{8n^4}\] \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{a_n}{b_n} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{\frac{3n + 3}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4}}{\frac{3}{8n^4}} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{3n + 3}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4} \times \frac{8n^4}{3} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8n^5 + 8n^4}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8 + \frac{8}{n}}{8 + \frac{2}{n^3} + \frac{4}{n^5}} \\ &= 1 \end{align}\] \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{3}{8n^4}\) converges (p-series test). \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{3n + 3}{8n^5 + 2n^2 + 4}\) converges from the limit comparison test. Theorem 6.6 (Ratio Test) Given the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) with \(a_k > 0\). Let \[\lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} = L\] The ratio test states the following: If \(L < 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges. If \(L > 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) diverges. If \(L = 1\), then the test is inconclusive (the series may be divergent or conditionally convergent). Example 6.13 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^k}{k!}\) converges or diverges. Let \(a_k = \frac{2^k}{k!}\). \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\frac{2^{k+1}}{(k+1)!}}{\frac{2^k}{k!}} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{2^{k+1}}{(k+1)!} \times \frac{k!}{2^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{2}{k+1} \\ &= 0 \end{align}\] Since \(L < 1\), \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^k}{k!}\) converges from the ratio test. Example 6.14 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} \frac{k^k}{k!}\) converges or diverges. Let \(a_k = \frac{k^k}{k!}\). \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\frac{(k+1)^{k+1}}{(k+1)!}}{\frac{k^k}{k!}} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{k+1}}{(k+1)!} \times \frac{k!}{k^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{(k+1)^k}{k^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)^k \\ &= e \end{align}\] Since \(L > 1\), \(\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} \frac{k^k}{k!}\) diverges from the ratio test. Theorem 6.7 (Root Test) Given the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) with \(a_k > 0\). Let \[\lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{a_k} = L\] If \(L < 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges. If \(L > 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) diverges. If \(L = 1\), then the test is inconclusive. Example 6.15 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} \left(\frac{\ln k}{k}\right)^k\) converges or diverges. Let \(a_k = \left(\frac{\ln k}{k}\right)^k\). \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{a_k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{\left(\frac{\ln k}{k}\right)^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\ln k}{k} \\ &= 0 \end{align}\] Since \(L < 1\), \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{\ln k}{k}\right)^k\) converges from the root test. Example 6.16 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} \left(\frac{4k}{3k+2}\right)^k\) converges or diverges. Let \(a_k = \left(\frac{4k}{3k+2}\right)^k\). \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{a_k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{\left(\frac{4k}{3k+2}\right)^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{4k}{3k+2} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{4k^{1/k}}{(3k+2)^{1/k}} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{4}{3^{1 + \frac{2}{k}}} \\ &= \frac{4}{3} \end{align}\] Since \(L > 1\), \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{4k}{3k+2}\right)^k\) diverges from the root test. Definition 6.3 An alternating series is any series which can be written in one of the following two forms: \[\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k \quad \text{or} \quad \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1} a_k\] where \(a_k > 0\) for all \(k\). Theorem 6.8 (Alternating Series Test) An alternating series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k\) or \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1} a_k\) converges if both of the following conditions are satisfied: \(\lim_{k \to \infty} a_k = 0\) \(\{a_k\}\) is a decreasing sequence; that is, \(a_{k+1} < a_k\) for all \(k\). Remark. Alone, not satisfying the hypotheses of the Alternating Series Test is not sufficient reason to conclude that the series does not converge. The theorem says that if its conditions are satisfied, then the series converges. If the conditions are not satisfied, the test is inconclusive. Example 6.17 Determine whether \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^n}{n}\) converges or diverges. The series can be expressed as \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^n a_n\), where \(a_n = \frac{1}{n}\). We have \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0\). Since \(\frac{1}{n+1} < \frac{1}{n}\) for all \(n > 0\), the sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is decreasing. Thus the alternating series test tells us that the given series must converge. Example 6.18 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \sin\left(\frac{k\pi}{2}\right) \frac{\ln(k)}{k}\) converges or diverges. \(k\) \(1\) \(2\) \(3\) \(4\) \(5\) \(6\) \(\sin\left(\dfrac{k\pi}{2}\right)\) \(1\) \(0\) \(-1\) \(0\) \(1\) \(0\) \(\dfrac{\ln(k)}{k}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(1)}{1}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(2)}{2}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(3)}{3}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(4)}{4}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(5)}{5}\) \(\dfrac{\ln(6)}{6}\) \[\begin{align} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \sin\left(\frac{k\pi}{2}\right) \frac{\ln(k)}{k} &= \frac{\ln(1)}{1} + 0 - \frac{\ln(3)}{3} + 0 + \frac{\ln(5)}{5} + 0 - \frac{\ln(7)}{7} + \cdots \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1} \frac{\ln(2k-1)}{2k-1} \\ &= \frac{\ln(1)}{1} - \frac{\ln(3)}{3} + \frac{\ln(5)}{5} - \frac{\ln(7)}{7} + \cdots \end{align}\] The series can be expressed as \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n+1} a_n\), where \(a_k = \frac{\ln(2k-1)}{2k-1}\). Let \(f(x) = \frac{\ln(2x-1)}{2x-1}\). \[\begin{align} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \frac{\ln(2x-1)}{2x-1} \\ &= \frac{(2x-1) \cdot 2 - (2x-1)^{-2} \cdot \ln(2x-1)}{(2x-1)^2} \\ &= \frac{2(1-\ln(2x-1))}{(2x-1)^2} \end{align}\] \((2x-1)^2 > 0\) for all \(x \in (1,\infty)\) and \((1-\ln(2x-1)) < 0\) for all \(x \geq \frac{e+1}{2}\). \(f'(x) < 0\), \(\forall x \geq \frac{e+1}{2}\). \(f(x)\) is decreasing for \(\forall x \geq \frac{e+1}{2}\) The sequence \(\{a_k\}\) is decreasing \(\forall k \geq \frac{e+1}{2}\) \[\begin{align} \lim_{n \to \infty} a_k &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{\ln(2k-1)}{2k-1} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{\ln(n)}{n} \quad \text{(Let $n = 2k-1$, then $k \to \infty \Rightarrow n \to \infty$)} \\ &= 0 \end{align}\] \(\lim_{k \to \infty} a_k = 0\) and \(\{a_k\}\) is a decreasing sequence. Thus alternating test tells us that the given series must converge. Example 6.19 Determine whether \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n+1} \frac{(2n^2+1)}{n^2+2}\) converges or diverges. Series can be expressed as \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^n a_n\), where \(a_n = \frac{2n^2+1}{n^2+2}\). \[\begin{align} \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n^2+1}{n^2+2} &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2 + \frac{1}{n^2}}{1 + \frac{2}{n^2}} = 2 \neq 0 \end{align}\] So, the first condition isn’t met and so there is no reason to check the second. Since this condition isn’t met we’ll need to use another test to check convergence. In these cases where the first condition isn’t met it is usually best to use the divergence test. First part of \((-1)^{n+1} \frac{(2n^2+1)}{n^2+2}\) just alternates between positive and negative values that are getting closer and closer to \(-2\) and \(2\), Thus \(\lim_{n \to \infty} (-1)^{n+1} \frac{(2n^2+1)}{n^2+2}\) is undefined and so by the Divergence Test this series diverges. Theorem 6.9 (Alternating P-series) The series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{k^p}\) is called the alternating P-series. The alternating P-series converges for all \(P > 0\). \end{theorem} Theorem 6.10 (Error Estimates for alternating Series) Suppose the alternating series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^k a_k\) or \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{k+1} a_k\) satisfies the conditions of the alternating series tests (namely \(\lim_{k \to \infty} a_k = 0\) and \(\{a_k\}\) is decreasing). If the series has sum \(S\), then \[|S - S_n| \leq a_{n+1}\] where \(S_n\) is the \(n\)th partial sum of the series. 6.4 Absolutely Convergence and Conditional Convergence Definition 6.4 A series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) is called absolutely convergent if \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} |a_k|\) is convergent. The series \(\sum_{k=1}^\infty\)a_k is conditionally convergent If \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges but \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} |a_k|\) diverges. Example 6.20 Determine whether the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^n}{n}\) converges or diverges. The series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^n}{n}\) converges (alternating series test) but \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left|\frac{(-1)^n}{n}\right| = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n}\) diverges (harmonic series) Therefore the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^n}{n}\) conditionally converges. Theorem 6.11 (Generalized Ratio Test) Given the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) Let, \[\lim_{k \to \infty} \left|\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k}\right| = L\] If \(L > 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) diverges. If \(L = 1\), then the test is inconclusive (The series may be divergent or conditionally convergent) Theorem 6.12 (Absolute Convergent Test) A series of real numbers \(\sum a_k\) must converges if the related absolute value series \(\sum |a_k|\) converges. Example 6.21 Determine whether \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(k)(2)^k}{k!|\sin(k)|}\) converges or diverges. Because \(\sin(k)\) take both positive and negative values, the series cannot analyzed by methods that apply only to series of positive terms. Moreover, note that series is not strictly alternating. Let \(a_k = \frac{\sin(k)(2)^k}{k!|\sin(k)|} = \frac{|\sin(k)|(2)^k}{k!|\sin(k)|} = \frac{2^k}{k!}\) \[\begin{align} L &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{2^{k+1}}{(k+1)!} \cdot \frac{k!}{2^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{2^{k+1}}{(k+1)!} \cdot \frac{k!}{2^k} \\ &= \lim_{k \to \infty} \left(\frac{2}{k+1}\right) \\ &= 0 \end{align}\] \(L < 1\), hence \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges from Ratio Test. \(\therefore \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\sin(k)(2)^k}{k!|\sin(k)|}\) converges from Absolute Convergent Test. we can use this above idea to generalize the test’s for positive series: Theorem 6.13 (Generalized Ratio Test) Given the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) Let, \[\lim_{k \to \infty} \left|\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k}\right| = L\] where \(L\) is a real number or \(\infty\) then The generalized ratio test states the followings: If \(L < 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges. If \(L = 1\), then the test is inconclusive (The series may be divergent or conditionally convergent) Theorem 6.14 (Generalized Root Test) Given the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) with \(a_k > 0\) Let, \[\lim_{k \to \infty} \sqrt[k]{|a_k|} = L\] The generalized root test states the followings: If \(L < 1\), then the series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges.
